Some info on Romanian wasr rifles. some people dislike wasr rifles because they have a reputation for being poorly built from spare parts kits. This may be true for some rifles produced while their quality control was lax/different management. This rifle however is built from all number matching parts. As well as chrome lined barrel.   some extra little known info about some ak 47 pattern rifles I wont name any names to not piss off other sellers on armslist do some research and you will find the brands im mentioning. To import ak's they modified the rifles to only accept single stack magazines in doing so some manufacturers simply built new forward trunions narrowed the stripper lug on the bolt and stamped new sheet metal receivers  these new parts were to make the rifle accept the single stack magazines for importation. Wasr rifles are built with all standard military internals (most importantly double stack capable forward trunion and bolt.) the only thing they do on wasr's is stamp a new sheet metal receiver that is single stack and throw all of the military parts back in. After importation the sheet metal is cut to widen the mag well to accept double stack magazines and 922r parts are added. This is true for many ak's however the catch for some ak's NOT WASR's is that the internal trunion has to be milled out as well as the sheet metal and much of the time the narrow bolt is reused  put these three things together and you get feed issues/mag wobble with some guns. Because wasr's only need one cut to be made on sheet metal there is less work and thus less error.  (trunion is the part that the barrel and receiver are attached to as well as the magazine. stamped ak's have two trunions a forward and a rear the rear accepts the stock)(look up 922r yourself)  ill stop with the talk.

title: For Sale:  Reliable (please read on) Davis .380 Pocket Auto
location: Santa Fe, NM, New Mexico, United States
postcontent:
Ok, I am an idiot. I listed this gun on Thursday morning and got about a dozen emails on it. I gave the first guy who emailed me a call and he said he would take it. So being the trusting fool I am, I thanked the other inquirers and deactivated this listing.  The guy even told me how he hated for people to stiff him on Armslist. Never happened to me here but I empathized with him. What does he do to me besides stringing me out  for 2 days? You guessed it. Now he wanted even more time. For an $85 gun. So now here I am wih a reactivated ad. Please don't arrange to meet me and have me rearrange my day off twice if you don't have 85 bucks. I am not trying to be a jerk here, but it's 85 freaking dollars. I know 85 dollars is a lot of money to a lot of people. But this guy was telling me about his AR15 and quad rails and acting like he was my friend. I wouldn't doubt it if this pistol is worth exactly $85 more than his imaginary AR. I just had to get this off my chest. Gun people are normally honorable so I'm guessing this guy isn't one of us anyway. 
Now back to the gun...This one is a really good gun, and I am only selling this one (and a couple of others already sold) so I can piddle around and rescue some more. Once they are finished, I generally lose interest and go on to the next project gun. But not until I am sure they are dead reliable. This one comes with two original magazines. Since tuning, it is dead nuts reliable with 6 rounds instead of the 5 rounds marked on it. I have hand fitted both mags as well and they work great.

What is there to say? This is a good shooting handgun that is accurate and functions perfectly. I have a bunch of these, and I have learned how to tune them to make them reliable. This is one of those. Since it has a fixed barrel it happens to also be accurate. I routinely shoot spent shotgun  shells at 20-30 yards with these. On this particular one I tuned it and added three dot fluorescent orange sights. Lol, I actually drilled all the way through my left index finger when I was drilling the dimples. so this one has my blood, sweat, and tears invested in it.

The best part is...where else can you find a reliable semiauto pistol in a serious caliber(.380 ACP) with 2 mags for $85 ? They make a great car gun or just plink with it like I do.  I had one failure to feed and that was while I was intentionally trying to limp wrist it using flat point bullets. Other than that it has been perfect. 

Contact me through Armslist and we can arrange to meet in Santa Fe any time. I will show you how to keep it running great indefinitely. These are neat little guns despite their low price. They just need some initial tweaking since they were made to be sold at a very low price point. I have done this. I have lots of very expensive handguns, but nothing puts a smile on my face more than outshooting a $500 pistol with a cheap little auto.

Thanks for reading my ad.

This is an original Allen & Thurber 5 barrel Pepperbox.  Everything is original...it has not been refurbished.
This gun is fully functional.
The gun was manufactured in 1847 and came west to Utah with the pioneers in 1848.  
Allen & Thurber manufactured the pepperbox pistols that were used by both Joseph Smith and Brigham Young.
The Allen & Thurber pepperboxes were very popular with the Mormon pioneers.
The gun originally sold for $8.25 while a similar model of equal quality was sold by Colt for $8.75.  The Mormons, being thrifty, chose the less expensive Allen & Thurber model.
You will notice that the color of the barrels is different then the color of thr frame.  This is typical of the guns used by the LDS pioneers.  This because the pioneers used their guns, rather then just carried the gun.  The heat from the barrel over time caused the changed in color.
The gun is about a 32 caliber.  It is a cap and ball pistol that was manufactured before 1889 so it can be sold and shipped directly without having to go through an FFL dealer.

This is an original Allen & Thurber 5 barrel Pepperbox.  Everything is original…it has not been refurbished.
This gun is fully functional.
The gun was manufactured in 1847 and came west to Utah with the pioneers in 1848.  
Allen & Thurber manufactured the pepperbox pistols that were used by both Joseph Smith and Brigham Young.
The Allen & Thurber pepperboxes were very popular with the Mormon pioneers.
The gun originally sold for $8.25 while a similar model of equal quality was sold by Colt for $8.75.  The Mormons, being thrifty, chose the less expensive Allen & Thurber model.
You will notice that the color of the barrels is different then the color of thr frame.  This is typical of the guns used by the LDS pioneers.  This because the pioneers used their guns, rather then just carried the gun.  The heat from the barrel over time caused the changed in color.
